byline.contributor: Alison Smale contributed reporting from Berlin.

abstract: Central Intelligence Agency director John Brennan scores 'hand-wringing' over intrusive government espionage and says intelligence leaks have impeded identification of Islamic State suspects; civil libertarians warn government, due to fear over terrorism, will strive for new and uncalled-for authorities on espionage in wake of recent events like Paris assaults.
lead_paragraph: The director, John O. Brennan, criticized “hand-wringing” over spying by governments and said that restrictions on surveillance made it harder to find terrorists.

headline.main: After Paris Attacks, C.I.A. Director Rekindles Debate Over Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Gloves Off, Director of the C.I.A. Faults Surveillance Curbs

snippet: The director, John O. Brennan, criticized “hand-wringing” over spying by governments and said that restrictions on surveillance made it harder to find terrorists.
